sn55.40:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.
sn55.40:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

sn55.40:1.2.pli: Atha kho nandiyo sakko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho nandiyo sakko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn55.40:1.2.eng: Then Nandiya the Sakyan went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn55.40:1.3.pli: “yasseva nu kho, bhante, ariyasāvakassa cattāri sotāpattiyaṅgāni sabbena sabbaṃ sabbathā sabbaṃ natthi sveva nu kho, bhante, ariyasāvako pamādavihārī”ti.
sn55.40:1.3.eng: “Sir, if a noble disciple were to totally and utterly lack the four factors of stream-entry, would they live negligently?”

sn55.40:2.1.pli: “‘Yassa kho, nandiya, cattāri sotāpattiyaṅgāni sabbena sabbaṃ sabbathā sabbaṃ natthi tamahaṃ bāhiro puthujjanapakkhe ṭhito’ti vadāmi.
sn55.40:2.1.eng: “Nandiya, someone who totally and utterly lacks these four factors of stream-entry is an outsider who belongs with the ordinary persons, I say.

sn55.40:2.2.pli: Api ca, nandiya, yathā ariyasāvako pamādavihārī ceva hoti, appamādavihārī ca
sn55.40:2.2.eng: Neverthless, Nandiya, as to how a noble disciple lives negligently and how they live diligently,

sn55.40:2.3.pli: taṃ suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn55.40:2.3.eng: listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn55.40:2.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho nandiyo sakko bhagavato paccassosi.

sn55.40:3.1.eng: “And how does a noble disciple live negligently?

sn55.40:3.2.pli: Idha, nandiya, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.40:3.2.eng: Firstly, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.40:3.3.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.40:3.4.pli: So tena buddhe aveccappasādena santuṭṭho na uttari vāyamati divā pavivekāya, rattiṃ paṭisallānāya.
sn55.40:3.4.eng: They’re content with that confidence, and don’t make a further effort for solitude by day or retreat by night.

sn55.40:3.5.pli: Tassa evaṃ pamattassa viharato pāmojjaṃ na hoti.
sn55.40:3.5.eng: When they live negligently, there’s no joy.

sn55.40:3.6.eng: When there’s no joy, there’s no rapture.

sn55.40:3.7.eng: When there’s no rapture, there’s no tranquility.

sn55.40:3.8.eng: When there’s no tranquility, there’s suffering.

sn55.40:3.9.eng: When one is suffering, the mind does not become immersed in samādhi.

sn55.40:3.10.eng: When the mind is not immersed in samādhi, principles do not become clear.

sn55.40:3.11.eng: Because principles have not become clear, they’re reckoned to live negligently.

sn55.40:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the teaching …

sn55.40:4.3.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.40:4.3.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.40:4.4.pli: So tehi ariyakantehi sīlehi santuṭṭho na uttari vāyamati divā pavivekāya rattiṃ paṭisallānāya.
sn55.40:4.4.eng: They’re content with that ethical conduct loved by the noble ones, and don’t make a further effort for solitude by day or retreat by night.

sn55.40:4.5.pli: Tassa evaṃ pamattassa viharato pāmojjaṃ na hoti.
sn55.40:4.5.eng: When they live negligently, there’s no joy.

sn55.40:4.6.eng: When there’s no joy, there’s no rapture.

sn55.40:4.7.eng: When there’s no rapture, there’s no tranquility.

sn55.40:4.8.eng: When there’s no tranquility, there’s suffering.

sn55.40:4.9.eng: When one is suffering, the mind does not become immersed in samādhi.

sn55.40:4.10.eng: When the mind is not immersed in samādhi, principles do not become clear.

sn55.40:4.11.eng: Because principles have not become clear, they’re reckoned to live negligently.

sn55.40:4.12.pli: Evaṃ kho, nandiya, ariyasāvako pamādavihārī hoti.
sn55.40:4.12.eng: That’s how a noble disciple lives negligently.

sn55.40:5.1.eng: And how does a noble disciple live diligently?

sn55.40:5.2.pli: Idha, nandiya, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.40:5.2.eng: Firstly, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.40:5.3.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.40:5.4.pli: So tena buddhe aveccappasādena asantuṭṭho uttari vāyamati divā pavivekāya rattiṃ paṭisallānāya.
sn55.40:5.4.eng: But they’re not content with that confidence, and make a further effort for solitude by day and retreat by night.

sn55.40:5.5.pli: Tassa evaṃ appamattassa viharato pāmojjaṃ jāyati.
sn55.40:5.5.eng: When they live diligently, joy springs up.

sn55.40:5.7.eng: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.

sn55.40:5.8.eng: When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss.

sn55.40:5.9.eng: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

sn55.40:5.10.eng: When the mind is immersed in samādhi, principles become clear.

sn55.40:5.11.eng: Because principles have become clear, they’re reckoned to live diligently.

sn55.40:6.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the teaching …

sn55.40:6.3.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.40:6.3.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.40:6.4.pli: So tehi ariyakantehi sīlehi asantuṭṭho uttari vāyamati divā pavivekāya rattiṃ paṭisallānāya.
sn55.40:6.4.eng: But they’re not content with that ethical conduct loved by the noble ones, and make a further effort for solitude by day and retreat by night.

sn55.40:6.5.pli: Tassa evaṃ appamattassa viharato pāmojjaṃ jāyati.
sn55.40:6.5.eng: When they live diligently, joy springs up.

sn55.40:6.7.eng: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.

sn55.40:6.8.eng: When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss.

sn55.40:6.9.eng: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

sn55.40:6.10.eng: When the mind is immersed in samādhi, principles become clear.

sn55.40:6.11.eng: Because principles have become clear, they’re reckoned to live diligently.

sn55.40:6.12.pli: Evaṃ kho, nandiya, ariyasāvako appamādavihārī hotī”ti.
sn55.40:6.12.eng: That’s how a noble disciple lives diligently.”

sn55.41:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.

sn55.41:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.41:1.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.41:1.4.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.41:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.41:3.1.eng: Furthermore, they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion. …

sn55.41:3.3.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro puññābhisandā, kusalābhisandā, sukhassāhārā.
sn55.41:3.3.eng: These are the four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.

sn55.41:4.1.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi puññābhisandehi kusalābhisandehi samannāgatassa ariyasāvakassa na sukaraṃ puññassa pamāṇaṃ gaṇetuṃ:
sn55.41:4.1.eng: When a noble disciple has these four kinds of overflowing merit and goodness, it’s not easy to measure how much merit they have by saying that

sn55.41:4.2.eng: this is the extent of their overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.

sn55.41:4.3.pli: Atha kho asaṅkhyeyyo appameyyo mahāpuññakkhandhotveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchati.
sn55.41:4.3.eng: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of merit.

sn55.41:5.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, mahāsamudde na sukaraṃ udakassa pamāṇaṃ gaṇetuṃ:
sn55.41:5.1.eng: It’s like trying to measure how much water is in the ocean. It’s not easy to say

sn55.41:5.2.pli: ‘ettakāni udakāḷhakānī’ti vā ‘ettakāni udakāḷhakasatānī’ti vā ‘ettakāni udakāḷhakasahassānī’ti vā ‘ettakāni udakāḷhakasatasahassānī’ti vāti.
sn55.41:5.2.eng: how many gallons, how many hundreds, thousands, hundreds of thousands of gallons there are.

sn55.41:5.3.pli: Atha kho asaṅkhyeyyo appameyyo mahāudakakkhandhotveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchati.
sn55.41:5.3.eng: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of water.

sn55.41:5.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, imehi catūhi puññābhisandehi kusalābhisandehi samannāgatassa ariyasāvakassa na sukaraṃ puññassa pamāṇaṃ gaṇetuṃ:
sn55.41:5.4.eng: In the same way, when a noble disciple has these four kinds of overflowing merit and goodness, it’s not easy to measure how much merit they have by saying that

sn55.41:5.5.eng: this is the extent of their overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.

sn55.41:5.6.pli: Atha kho asaṅkhyeyyo appameyyo mahāpuññakkhandhotveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchatī”ti.
sn55.41:5.6.eng: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of merit.”

sn55.41:6.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn55.41:6.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn55.41:6.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn55.41:7.2.eng: and though the rivers are many,

sn55.41:7.3.eng: all reach the great deep, the boundless ocean,

sn55.41:7.4.eng: the cruel sea that’s home to precious gems.

sn55.41:8.1.eng: So too, when a person gives food, drink, and clothes;

sn55.41:8.2.eng: and they’re a giver of beds, seats, and mats—

sn55.41:8.3.eng: the streams of merit reach that astute person,

sn55.41:8.4.eng: as the rivers bring their waters to the sea.”

sn55.42:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.

sn55.42:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.42:1.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.42:1.4.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.42:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati muttacāgo payatapāṇi vossaggarato yācayogo dānasaṃvibhāgarato.
sn55.42:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.

sn55.42:3.2.eng: This is the fourth kind of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.

sn55.42:3.3.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro puññābhisandā, kusalābhisandā, sukhassāhārā.
sn55.42:3.3.eng: These are the four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.

sn55.42:4.1.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi puññābhisandehi kusalābhisandehi samannāgatassa ariyasāvakassa na sukaraṃ puññassa pamāṇaṃ gaṇetuṃ:
sn55.42:4.1.eng: When a noble disciple has these four kinds of overflowing merit and goodness, it’s not easy to measure how much merit they have by saying that

sn55.42:4.2.eng: this is the extent of their overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.

sn55.42:4.3.pli: Atha kho asaṅkhyeyyo appameyyo mahāpuññakkhandhotveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchati.
sn55.42:4.3.eng: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of merit.

sn55.42:5.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yatthimā mahānadiyo saṃsandanti samenti, seyyathidaṃ—
sn55.42:5.1.eng: There are places where the great rivers—the Ganges, Yamuna, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—join together and converge.

sn55.42:5.2.pli: gaṅgā, yamunā, aciravatī, sarabhū, mahī, tattha na sukaraṃ udakassa pamāṇaṃ gaṇetuṃ:
sn55.42:5.2.eng: It’s not easy to measure how much water is in such places by saying

sn55.42:5.3.pli: ‘ettakāni udakāḷhakānī’ti vā ‘ettakāni udakāḷhakasatānī’ti vā ‘ettakāni udakāḷhakasahassānī’ti vā ‘ettakāni udakāḷhakasatasahassānī’ti vāti.
sn55.42:5.3.eng: how many gallons, how many hundreds, thousands, hundreds of thousands of gallons there are.

sn55.42:5.4.pli: Atha kho asaṅkhyeyyo appameyyo mahāudakakkhandhotveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchati.
sn55.42:5.4.eng: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of water.

sn55.42:5.5.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, imehi catūhi puññābhisandehi kusalābhisandehi samannāgatassa ariyasāvakassa na sukaraṃ puññassa pamāṇaṃ gaṇetuṃ:
sn55.42:5.5.eng: In the same way, when a noble disciple has these four kinds of overflowing merit and goodness, it’s not easy to measure how much merit they have by saying that

sn55.42:5.6.eng: this is the extent of their overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.

sn55.42:5.7.pli: Atha kho asaṅkhyeyyo appameyyo mahāpuññakkhandhotveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchatī”ti.
sn55.42:5.7.eng: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of merit.”

sn55.42:5.8.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn55.42:5.9.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn55.42:6.2.eng: and though the rivers are many,

sn55.42:6.3.eng: all reach the great deep, the boundless ocean,

sn55.42:6.4.eng: the cruel sea that’s home to precious gems.

sn55.42:7.1.eng: So too, when a person gives food, drink, and clothes;

sn55.42:7.2.eng: and they’re a giver of beds, seats, and mats—

sn55.42:7.3.eng: the streams of merit reach that astute person,

sn55.42:7.4.eng: as the rivers bring their waters to the sea.”

sn55.43:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.

sn55.43:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.43:1.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.43:1.4.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.43:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
sn55.43:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

sn55.43:3.2.eng: This is the fourth kind of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.

sn55.43:3.3.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro puññābhisandā kusalābhisandā sukhassāhārā.
sn55.43:3.3.eng: These are the four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.

sn55.43:4.1.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi puññābhisandehi kusalābhisandehi samannāgatassa ariyasāvakassa na sukaraṃ puññassa pamāṇaṃ gaṇetuṃ:
sn55.43:4.1.eng: When a noble disciple has these four kinds of overflowing merit and goodness, it’s not easy to measure how much merit they have by saying that

sn55.43:4.2.eng: this is the extent of their overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.

sn55.43:4.3.pli: Atha kho asaṅkhyeyyo appameyyo mahāpuññakkhandhotveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchatī”ti.
sn55.43:4.3.eng: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of merit.”

sn55.43:4.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn55.43:4.5.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn55.43:5.1.eng: “One who desires merit, grounded in the skillful,

sn55.43:5.2.eng: develops the path to realize freedom from death.

sn55.43:5.3.eng: Once they’ve reached the heart of the teaching, <j>delighting in ending,

sn55.43:5.4.eng: they don’t tremble at the approach <j>of the King of Death.”

sn55.44:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako ‘aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo’ti vuccati.
sn55.44:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a noble disciple who has four things is said to be rich, affluent, and wealthy.

sn55.44:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.44:2.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.44:2.3.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti;

sn55.44:2.6.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.44:2.6.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.44:2.7.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako ‘aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo’ti vuccatī”ti.
sn55.44:2.7.eng: A noble disciple who has these four things is said to be rich, affluent, and wealthy.”

sn55.45:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako ‘aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo mahāyaso’ti vuccati.
sn55.45:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a noble disciple who has four things is said to be rich, affluent, wealthy, and famous.

sn55.45:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.45:2.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.45:2.3.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.45:2.6.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.45:2.6.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.45:2.7.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako ‘aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo mahāyaso’ti vuccatī”ti.
sn55.45:2.7.eng: A noble disciple who has these four things is said to be rich, affluent, wealthy, and famous.”

sn55.46:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo.
sn55.46:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a noble disciple who has four things is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

sn55.46:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.46:2.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.46:2.3.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.46:2.6.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.46:2.6.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.46:2.7.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.
sn55.46:2.7.eng: A noble disciple who has these four things is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn55.47:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho nandiyaṃ sakkaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn55.47:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, the Buddha said to Nandiya the Sakyan:

sn55.47:1.3.pli: “catūhi kho, nandiya, dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo.
sn55.47:1.3.eng: “Nandiya, a noble disciple who has four things is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

sn55.47:2.2.pli: Idha, nandiya, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.47:2.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.47:2.3.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.47:2.6.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.47:2.6.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.47:2.7.pli: Imehi kho, nandiya, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.
sn55.47:2.7.eng: A noble disciple who has these four things is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn55.48:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho bhaddiyaṃ sakkaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn55.48:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, the Buddha said to Bhaddiya the Sakyan:

sn55.48:1.3.pli: “catūhi kho, bhaddiya, dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo.
sn55.48:1.3.eng: “Bhaddiya, a noble disciple who has four things is a stream-enterer …”

sn55.48:2.5.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.

sn55.48:2.6.pli: Imehi kho, bhaddiya, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.

sn55.49:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho mahānāmaṃ sakkaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn55.49:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, the Buddha said to Mahānāma the Sakyan:

sn55.49:1.3.pli: “catūhi kho, mahānāma, dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sotāpanno hoti …pe… sambodhiparāyaṇo.
sn55.49:1.3.eng: “Mahānāma, a noble disciple who has four things is a stream-enterer …”

sn55.49:2.5.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.

sn55.49:2.6.pli: Imehi kho, mahānāma, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.

sn55.5:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn55.5:1.1.eng: Then Sāriputta went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

sn55.5:1.2.eng: “Sāriputta, they speak of a ‘factor of stream-entry’.

sn55.5:1.3.eng: What is a factor of stream-entry?”

sn55.5:1.4.pli: “Sappurisasaṃsevo hi, bhante, sotāpattiyaṅgaṃ, saddhammassavanaṃ sotāpattiyaṅgaṃ, yonisomanasikāro sotāpattiyaṅgaṃ, dhammānudhammappaṭipatti sotāpattiyaṅgan”ti.
sn55.5:1.4.eng: “Sir, the factors of stream-entry are associating with true persons, listening to the true teaching, rational application of mind, and practicing in line with the teaching.”

sn55.5:1.6.pli: Sappurisasaṃsevo hi, sāriputta, sotāpattiyaṅgaṃ, saddhammassavanaṃ sotāpattiyaṅgaṃ, yonisomanasikāro sotāpattiyaṅgaṃ, dhammānudhammappaṭipatti sotāpattiyaṅgaṃ.
sn55.5:1.6.eng: For the factors of stream-entry are associating with true persons, listening to the true teaching, rational application of mind, and practicing in line with the teaching.

sn55.5:2.3.pli: “Ayameva hi, bhante, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo soto, seyyathidaṃ—
sn55.5:2.3.eng: “Sir, the stream is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn55.5:2.4.pli: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhī”ti.
sn55.5:2.4.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.”

sn55.5:2.6.pli: Ayameva hi, sāriputta, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo soto, seyyathidaṃ—
sn55.5:2.6.eng: For the stream is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn55.5:2.7.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn55.5:3.3.pli: “Yo hi, bhante, iminā ariyena aṭṭhaṅgikena maggena samannāgato ayaṃ vuccati sotāpanno, svāyaṃ āyasmā evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto”ti.
sn55.5:3.3.eng: “Sir, anyone who possesses this noble eightfold path is called a stream-enterer, the venerable of such and such name and clan.”

sn55.5:3.5.pli: Yo hi, sāriputta, iminā ariyena aṭṭhaṅgikena maggena samannāgato ayaṃ vuccati sotāpanno, svāyaṃ āyasmā evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto”ti.
sn55.5:3.5.eng: For anyone who possesses this noble eightfold path is called a stream-enterer, the venerable of such and such name and clan.”

sn55.50:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four factors of stream-entry.

sn55.50:1.3.eng: Associating with true persons, listening to the true teaching, rational application of mind, and practicing in line with the teaching.

sn55.50:1.4.eng: These are the four factors of stream-entry.”

sn55.51:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo.
sn55.51:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a noble disciple who has four things is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

sn55.51:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.51:2.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.51:2.3.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.51:2.6.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.51:2.6.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.51:2.7.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.
sn55.51:2.7.eng: A noble disciple who has these four things is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn55.51:2.8.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn55.51:2.9.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn55.51:2.9.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn55.51:3.1.eng: “Whoever has faith in the Realized One,

sn55.51:3.4.eng: praised and loved by the noble ones;

sn55.51:4.1.eng: who has confidence in the Saṅgha,

sn55.51:4.4.eng: their life is not in vain.

sn55.51:5.1.eng: So let the wise devote themselves

sn55.51:5.3.eng: confidence, and insight into the teaching,

sn55.51:5.4.eng: remembering the instructions of the Buddhas.”
